To my knowledge, the arena that they're going to be using is owned by a private company, so Private Property Laws apply.  And I respect the rights of Private Property and those people who choose to enforce or dictate whatever policies they wish to enact upon their owned property.  While I may not necessarily agree with it, I respect it all the same.

Do I agree or disagree with this issue altogether?  To be honest, I'm indifferent to Open-Carry.  I personally don't see a need to do it, and I've only done it once in public in my entire life.  The rest of the time, I carry concealed legally, and that works for me.

Out in a field or at a shooting range is one thing.  Not sure though if I agree with the logic of carrying one down the sidewalk outside of a mall or something like that.  While yes, they do have a right to do so (providing they live in a State that allows it), and I support their right to do so, I also have to question the logic in doing so.  What are they trying to accomplish?  And can that be accomplished equally by either carrying a handgun on the hip as opposed to an AR across the chest, or by perhaps wearing a T-shirt or holding a sign?

Saying that they're somehow going to be MORE in danger for open-carrying firearms at a Republican Convention is the same kind of nonsense as saying that gun shows are more dangerous because of a higher number of guns and ammunition in one place.  That kind of logic doesn't work in this situation.  MOST gun owners are law-abiding citizens who use guns safely.  And despite what the media wants the gullible to believe, they in fact DON'T react violently when confronted with tense situations or verbal confrontations (assuming they meet protesters).

@Kristian Brandt I don't know how things are in Denmark but there is an incredible amount of fluidity between the classes here, all you need to do is have your head on straight and not blow your time and money on garbage. I know quite a few people who have risen through the classes with the need of government intervention. Your assumptions about me couldn't be more wrong. I'm not in one dime of debt, I bust my ass off every summer and don't take out loans, and I don't belong to a fraternity. University isn't as expensive as you may think looking at the media.

The fraternaty thing was a bit on the immature side, I'm a slave to stereotypes, sorry about that. Worldwide American approval ratings have gone down quite a bit with the Trump presidency, and people are generalising Americans like it's going out of fashion. It's not fair, and I thought I was above it, but clearly it's starting to rub off.

You know I'm a teacher, but I have a degree in anthropology(human behavior), and my final exam was a piece on higher education around the world, and I did extensive research into the American educational system, and I'm afraid things are as bad as they seem. I don't practise alternative fact, numbers don't lie. 

I think it's great that you were able to make it on your own, truly, and so I sort of understand why you'd think that all it takes is to roll up your sleeves and get to work, and it is a romantic notion, but the sad truth is that some people just don't have that kind of drive. Flushing tax money into social services would allow those people to live a decent life with the cards they're dealt. 

I'd like to tell you something about myself. I suffer from a very mild case of epilepsy. I can be without seisures with medicine, I can even drive, but it is a chronic disease, I will have to take medicine every day for the rest of my life. In America I could not live the kind of decent lifestyle I have now. That's not fair, it's certainly not freedom, because I didn't choose to be ill.  

You can't realistically ''sink'' to our level, but at least make it realistic for a weaker individual to make it. For instance remove the ability for insurance companies to deny you because of pre existing conditions. I recently read an article about a baby being denied health insurance, because it was slightly overweight... That's not just wrong, it's downright cruel. 

Social tax would also help with issues like obesity. I believe the stereotype that all Americans are unintelligent is ridiculous, but the thing about stereotypes is that they're always based on watered down truth. We can disguss numbers all day, but the fact is that many Americans are grossly ill informed. Easy access to education would solve this. It'd also annialate FOX news ;)

Look you have your own opinion, and you're entitled to it, but I just can't see how you can claim socialism will fail, when our working class has a much higher standard of living than yours.

@Kristian Brandt Its fine, I think you'd be surprised to hear the majority of Americans couldn't give less of a shit what Europe thinks of us as long as we're at peace.
Thank you, it's why I get pissed when people say it isn't possible. I've worked 30+ hours a week all plus classes every semester straight out of school and more then double that in the summer without any help from my father. @irllcd13 if you wouldn't mind I'm having a conversation with @Kristian Brandt, I'll talk to you when we're done

Sorry this is a bit long :/ But like I said with the social services we're provided, services that working class Americans pay a lot of money to have, we're realistically walking away with more disposable income than your average American. We also have a much narrower wealth gap than you, and we have no absolute poverty, and you do. In case you're wondering there are two pillars of lower class poverty. The most common in western nations is relative poverty. Relative poverty means you're poor relative to your nation's standard of living. You can feed yourself, but you won't spend a romantic summer in Paris. Absolute poverty means you're actually having serious problems taking care of yourself, and you're one payment away from eviction. This is what you sometimes refer to as ''trailer trash''. Sadly this also means you have the highest percentage of child poverty of any wester n nation. If you still think privatised medicine is a good idea, then consider this. Not only do you have the lowest life expectancy of any weste rn nation, you also have the heighest infant mortality rate. Which is heartbreaking. This is why I say that looking from the outside, it seems that you genuinely despise each other. The top 30% must know this, and yet they're not willing to have their tax raised. Look, if you cut your defense spending, which is way too high, raise working class tax 15%, and tax the 1% as much as the working class, those numbers would improve dramatically. You have inner city schools that spend more on metal detectors and security than books which is just mad. And introducing advanced pedagogy to education would also help at risk students. It's hard to say how much people here pay, because tax is adjusted. People in my field usually pay around 40%, although I pay 50% because my master's degree gives me a slight pay raise, as does my Ph.D(wasn't going to mention that because it seems like boasting, but in this instance it's relevant). A slight tax raise would also enable you to look into the enviroment. I know many conservatives don't give two shits about this, but if you've ever been to Los Angeles, you'd know what I'm on about. As for my hypothetical life in America, I'm not sure you're right. My epilepsy didn't ''wake up'' till I was 14, however I was born with eczema. It went away after a few years, but it's still a pre-existing condition. I'm sorry if seem a bit zealous, but I just don't see how you can put a price on being healthy.

Also I'm not surprised many Americans don't care about world views, but these are the same people that claim to be the leaders of the world. How can you take pride in being a superpower when you allies don't respect you beyond your influence?

@Kristian Brandt Don't worry about it, we both have busy lives. I can't agree with your first point. $100,000 a year with 20% tax and less then $10,000 for for all of the same benefits is more then $40,000 with 50% + tax if not more, you don't need to be an engineer to see that. As for the wealth gap that argument is extremely weak when you start to analyze what it really means. Does it really matter that people like Bill Gates makes billions of dollars a year and I'll make maybe $250,000 annually by the end of my career? No. I want to do well for myself and I couldn't care less if 1% makes an outrageous amount of money. Yes Denmark has a small wealth gap but at the same time the average person is much poorer then the average American for it. Raising the taxes by 75% is completely unacceptable. Yes the infant mortality rate is high in America but the lives if 1.6% of children born is not an adequate reason for such an unreasonable hike in taxes. The defense budget is too expensive, I'll give you that. Personally I don't think we should spend a dime protecting nations that don't want us in the first place. The reasons the inner city's spend so much on security equipment is because the gang culture breeds violence, they really are necessary to keep the schools safe. Boast all you want, a PH.D is something to be proud of. I don't really have an opinion on the environment. I don't live near Los Angeles but all of the other cities I've been to a remarkably clean with the exception of Pittsburgh. I don't put a price on my personal health, but I'm not going to pay someone else's hospital bill. As for your final point let me put it like this: Denmark has a population of smaller then that of New York City. Do you really expect us to take the option of such a if relatively small country seriously?

Yeah I've always found that hilarious, you could fit our entire population in New York and still have room for 3 million more XD I didn't understand that last bit. I'm thinking what you ment to write was ''do you expect to take the opinions of such a small country seriously?''. If this is true, then I have to ask you to slow down, because you can't rule a nation irrelevant because of its size. The Vatican, which is actually a country, has the world's smallest population... Yet they house the richest and most influential corporation in the world, the Catholic church. Also we're actually quite a large country, because Greenland is Danish territory, and we haven't granted them independance yet. Although to be fair their total population is 50.000. I will absolutely agree that Americans have higher income than us, but our standard of living is still higher than yours because our tax is spent on shit which makes our lives better. I've been to Mexico, Jamaica, and New Zealand to name a few. I'm actually from Maryland which is actually an extremely liberal state. My name is actually a "Americanised" version of Schlagle which is German. I do plan on living in Texas after university because Petroleum engineers make more there then most places in the western world.

Ah cool, I studied in Auckland. It's a fantastic country. My American geography is awful, but isn't Maryland somewhere near Pennsylvania? Haha my name is unique to Scandinavia. Not sure if you've worked it out yet, but I'm not a woman. Many people read my name too fast, and get Kristen or Kirsten. In both English and Danish Kristian is pronounced exactly like Christian, it's just that Christ is ''Kristus'' in Danish, hence the K. I travel a lot and it's caused a few misunderstandings XD You're right we won't agree, but it's nice to meet a conservative mind that is actually open to argument, this was beautiful mate ;) So round two, GUN CONTROL!! @Michael Walsh I am an IMMENSE fan of Bernie, and I think he would be fantastic for our country (he's by far the best politician for the job), but he's a social democrat, much like Scandinavian countries are social democracies. Social democracy is left of center, and espouses many socialist ideals, but the fact still stands that it is a capitalist system with socialist elements, not a socialist country. Left of that is democratic socialism, and left of that is pure socialism. Social democrats like Bernie have a lot of really great ideas and could establish a great deal of good in the world, but in truth, he's not a full socialist (as he does NOT believe in social ownership of the means of production, at least not in practical terms).

But yes, regardless, we both support him and his beliefs, so it's important to be in favor of him. But I think that he would be a lot more electable to more people if his supporters would always clarify that he is a social democrat who does NOT want a full move to socialism. Three California cities have sought bankruptcy protection and there are constant rumors that more may soon follow. Among the problems impacting California cities are the huge debt obligations owed to CalPERS, the state's public employees' retirement system. For example, Stockton, one of the bankrupt cities, is paying CalPERS roughly $29 million a year, in addition to payments being made to other creditors. Number of Jobs — The economy has now added 7,865,000 jobs since Obama first took office.

Unemployment Rate — The unemployment rate continued to move downward, to 5.1 percent. It's now 2.7 percentage points lower than it was in January 2009, when the president first took office in the midst of the worst economic downturn since the Great Depression.

Long-term Unemployment — The number went down to just over 2.5 million in June, which is 578,000 fewer than when the president first took office.

Job Openings — The number of job openings increased further to 5,363,000 as of the last business day in May. The number of openings has gone up 94 percent since the month the president entered office.

Business Start-ups — New business establishments are opening at an accelerating pace. The Bureau of Labor Statistics counted 224,000 'births' of new establishments in the three months ending last September, the most recent period on record.
